speaker: Neil

speaker: Neil
text: One possible solution to this problem is to develop what is called a circular economy. Here’s the presenter of Business Daily, Manuela Saragosa, explaining what that means.

speaker: manufacturerlifecycleconsumer
text: The idea then at the core of a circular economic and business model is that a product, like say a washing machine or even a broom, can always be returned to the manufacturer to be reused or repaired before then sold on again. The point is the manufacturer retains responsibility for the lifecycle of the product it produces rather than the consumer assuming that responsibility when he or she buys it.

speaker: Neil
text: So it seems like a simple idea – though maybe very difficult to do.

speaker: manufacturerconsumer
text: Yes, the idea is that the company that makes a product, the manufacturer, is responsible for the product, not the person who bought it, the consumer.

speaker: lifecyclemanufacturer
text: So, if the product breaks or reaches the end of its useful life, its lifecycle, then the manufacturer has to take it back and fix, refurbish or have it recycled.

speaker: separate separate
text: Of course. To separate means to divide or split different things, for example, separate your plastic from your paper for recycling.

speaker: Treating
text: Treating is the word for dealing with, for example, recycled waste.

speaker: out of sight, out of mind
text: The phrase out of sight, out of mind, means ignoring something or a situation you can’t see.

speaker: manufacturer consumer
text: A manufacturer is the person or company that makes something and the consumer is the person who buys that thing.

speaker: lifecycle
text: And the length of time you can expect a product to work for is known as its lifecycle.
